case_name: Deputy Commercial Tax Officer v. The Madurai Mills Co., Ltd.

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 539 of 1965 is an appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated September 13, 1961 of the Madras High Court in T.C. No. 162 of 1958.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 539 of 1965. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated September 13, 1961 of the Madras High Court in T.C. No. 162 of 1958.

facts.text: The Madurai Mills Co., Ltd. is a dealer in yarn, purchasing raw material like cotton staple-fibre, manufacturing them into yarn and selling the yarn.

anchor.surface_text: TheMadurai Mills Co., Ltd.,  hereinafter called the respondent  isa dealer in yarn, purchasing raw material like companyton staple-fibre, etc., manufacturing them into yarn and selling the yarn.

facts.text: In the assessment year 1950-51, the respondent showed a return of Rs. 15,27,61,883-8-4 before the Deputy Commercial Tax Officer, Madurai.

anchor.surface_text: In the assessment year 1950-51, the respondent showed a return of Rs. 15,27,61,883-8-4 before the Deputy Commercial Tax Officer, Madurai who after scrutiny of the account books determined the net turnover at Rs. 15,44,09,109-3-1 1.

facts.text: Deputy Commercial Tax Officer, Madurai determined the net turnover at Rs. 15,44,09,109-3-1 after scrutiny of the account books.

anchor.surface_text: In the assessment year 1950-51, the respondent showed a return of Rs. 15,27,61,883-8-4 before the Deputy Commercial Tax Officer, Madurai who after scrutiny of the account books determined the net turnover at Rs. 15,44,09,109-3-1 1.

facts.text: The respondent preferred an appeal before the Commercial Tax Officer Madurai South.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent preferred an appeal before the Commercial Tax Officer Madurai South.

facts.text: Respondent contended that Rs. 1,44,294-14-4 was wrongly included in the purchase value of cotton as it represented commission paid to Comorin Investment Trading Company Limited.

anchor.surface_text: It was companytended on behalf of the respondent that a sum of Rs. 1,44,294-14-4 was wrongly included by the first assessing authority in the purchase value of companyton purchased by it for production of yarn as that amount only represented the companymission paid by it to Comorin Investment Trading Company Limited for the purchase

facts.text: Respondent contended that Rs. 81,546-0-1 represented sale proceeds of empty drums etc. not in the course of business.

anchor.surface_text: It was also companytended that another sum of Rs. 81,546-0-1 which represented sale proceeds realised by selling empty drums etc. was number realisation in the companyrse of its business.

facts.text: Commercial Tax Officer upheld the contention regarding Rs. 1,44,294-14-4 and excluded it from total turnover.

anchor.surface_text: The Commercial Tax Officer upheld the first companytention of the respondent and excluded the sum of Rs. 1,44,294-14-4 from the total turnover on the ground that the amount was companymission paid by the respondent for the purchase of companyton,

facts.text: Commercial Tax Officer rejected the contention regarding Rs. 81,546-0-1.

anchor.surface_text: but rejected their second companytention with regard to the sum of Rs. 81,546-0- 1.

facts.text: Deputy Commercial Tax Officer issued a revised assessment.

anchor.surface_text: The Deputy Commercial Tax Officer thereafter issued a revised assessment.

facts.text: Respondent presented a revision petition before the Deputy Commissioner of Commercial Taxes objecting to tax amounting to Rs. 6,57,971-4-9 collected by it.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent presented a revision petition before the Deputy Commissioner of Commercial Taxes and the only objection which the respondent raised was that it should number have been assessed to tax on amounts companylected by it by way ,of tax amounting to Rs. 6,57,971-4-9.

facts.text: Deputy Commissioner of Commercial Taxes dismissed the revision petition on August 21, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: By his order, dated the 21st August, 1954, the Deputy Commissioner of Commercial Taxes dismissed the revision petition holding that the respondent was number entitled to raise the companytention for the first time

facts.text: Board of Revenue issued a notice to the respondent on August 4, 1958 proposing to revise the assessment by including Rs. 7,74,62,706-1-6 wrongly excluded.

anchor.surface_text: On the 4th August, 1958, the Board of Revenue issued a numberice to the respondent stating that it proposed to revise the assessment of the Deputy Commercial Tax Officer, Madurai, by including in the net turnover the sum of Rs. 7,74,62,706-1-6 as that amount was wrongly excluded by the assessing authority.

facts.text: Respondent objected to Board of Revenue revision on ground of limitation under s. 12 of Madras General Sales Tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent objected to the proposed revision on the ground that the proceeding was barred by limitation under s. 12 of the Madras General Sales Tax Act.

facts.text: Respondent submitted there was no wrong exclusion of Rs. 7,74,62,706-1-6 by Deputy Commercial Tax Officer.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent also submitted -that there was numberwrong exclusion of the sum of Rs. 7,74,62,706-1-6 by the Deputy Commercial Tax Officer in making the assessment.

facts.text: Board of Revenue overruled respondent's contentions on August 25, 1958 and fixed net taxable turnover at Rs. 23,17,15,948-15-2.

anchor.surface_text: By its order, dated the 25th August, 1958, the Board of Revenue over-ruled both these companytentions of the respondent and fixed the net taxable turnover as Rs. 23,17,15,948-15-2.

facts.text: Madras High Court allowed respondent's appeal against Board of Revenue order, holding it could not invoke revisional jurisdiction after limitation under s.12(4)(b).

anchor.surface_text: The High Court allowed the appeal holding that the Board of Revenue companyld number invoke its revisional jurisdiction after the expiry of the period of limitation under s. 12  4  b  of the Madras General Sales Tax Act.

facts.text: Revised assessment order of Deputy Commercial Tax Officer, Madurai dated November 28, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: The only subject-matter of the revision proceedings before the Board of Revenue was the revised assessment order of the Deputy Commercial Tax Officer, Madurai dated the 28th November, 1952.

facts.text: Deputy Commercial Tax Officer allowed exemption on value of cotton purchased from outside the State of Madras.

anchor.surface_text: The objection taken by the Board of Revenue was with regard to the question of exemption allowed on the value of the companyton purchased from outside the State of Madras. The exemption was allowed by the Deputy Commercial Tax Officer in his order of assessment.

facts.text: Question of exemption was not raised before Deputy Commissioner of Commercial Taxes.

anchor.surface_text: The question was number raised before the Deputy Commissioner of Commercial Taxes and the only point raised before him was with regard to the inclusion of the amount of tax to the extent of Rs. 6,57,971-4-9 in the taxable turnover.

facts.text: Only point before Deputy Commissioner was inclusion of Rs. 6,57,971-4-9 tax collected in taxable turnover.

anchor.surface_text: It is manifest that the subject-matter of the revision proceedings before the Board of Revenue was the revised assessment order of the De- puty Commercial Tax Officer, Madurai dated the 28th November, 1952.

facts.text: Board of Revenue order dated August 25, 1958 was made after more than 4 years from communication of Deputy Commercial Tax Officer order.

anchor.surface_text: It follows that the order of the Board of Revenue was made beyond the limit of four years prescribed by s. 12 4  b  of the Act and it is, therefore, invalid.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds no merger of Deputy Commercial Tax Officer order dated November 28, 1952 with Deputy Commissioner order dated August 21, 1954 because exemption issue not raised before Deputy Commissioner.

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances of the present case, it cannot be said that there was a merger of the order of assessment made by the Deputy Commercial Tax Officer dated the 28th November, 1952 with the order of the Deputy Commissioner of Commercial Taxes dated the 21st August, 1954 because the question of exemption on the value of yarn purchased from outside the State of Madras was number the subject-matter of revision before the Deputy Commissioner of Commercial Taxes.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismisses the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: For these reasons, we hold that the judgment of the High Court is right and this appeal must be dismissed with companyts.

holdings.text: The order of the Board of Revenue dated the 25th August, 1958 was illegal because it contravened the rule of limitation laid down by s. 12(4)(b) of the Madras General Sales Tax Act as it was made after a period of 4 years from the date on which the order of the Deputy Commercial Tax Officer was communicated to the assessee.

anchor.surface_text: The question of law to be determined in this appeal is whether the order of the Board of Revenue dated the 25th August, 1958 was illegal because there was a contravention of the rule of limitation laid down by s. 12(4)(b) of the Madras General Sales Tax Act. The order

holdings.reasoning_summary: Board's revision targeted Dy CTO's revised assessment order dated 28 Nov 1952 regarding exemption on cotton purchases from outside State; this order communicated more than 4 years before Board's order; Dy Commr revision did not cover this issue.

holdings.text: The order revised by the Board of Revenue was the revised assessment order of the Deputy Commercial Tax Officer dated 28th November 1952 and not the revisional order of the Deputy Commissioner dated 21st August 1954.

anchor.surface_text: The only subject-matter of the revision proceedings before the Board of Revenue was the revised assessment order of the Deputy Commercial Tax Officer, Madurai dated the 28th November, 1952.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Board objected specifically to exemption allowed in Dy CTO order on cotton from outside Madras; this issue not raised before Dy Commr whose revision only addressed tax inclusion in turnover.

holdings.text: There was no merger of the Deputy Commercial Tax Officer order dated 28th November 1952 with the Deputy Commissioner order dated 21st August 1954 because the exemption issue was not the subject-matter before the Deputy Commissioner.

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances of the present case, it cannot be said that there was a merger of the order of assessment made by the Deputy Commercial Tax Officer dated the 28th November, 1952 with the order of the Deputy Commissioner of Commercial Taxes dated the 21st August, 1954 because the question of exemption on the value of yarn purchased from outside the State of Madras was not the subject-matter of revision before the Deputy Commissioner of Commercial Taxes.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Dy Commr only addressed inclusion of tax collected (Rs. 6,57,971); Board's revision addressed different issue (exclusion of Rs. 7.74 crores on inter-state cotton); merger requires same subject-matter.

holdings.text: The doctrine of merger is not a doctrine of rigid and universal application; it depends on the nature of the appellate or revisional order and the scope of the statutory provisions conferring jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: But the doctrine of merger is not a doctrine of rigid and universal application and it cannot be said that wherever there are two orders, one by the inferior Tribunal and the other by a superior Tribunal, passed in an appeal on revision, there is a fusion or merger of two orders irrespective of the subject-matter of the appellate or revisional order and the scope of the appeal or revision contemplated by the particular statute.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguished CIT v. Amritlal Bhogilal (registration not appealed) and State of UP v. Mohammed Nooh (no merger where issues differ); merger not automatic without overlapping subject-matter.

holdings.text: The judgment of the High Court is right and this appeal must be dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: For these reasons, we hold that the judgment of the High Court is right and this appeal must be dismissed with costs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affirmation of High Court based on above holdings on limitation and no-merger.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay v. Amritlal Bhogilal & Co.
precedents.cited_proposition: Doctrine of merger is not rigid and universal; no merger of orders if the specific order or aspect was not the subject-matter of the appeal or revision
precedents.cited_holding: order of registration made by the Income-tax Officer did number merge in the appellate order of the Appellate Commissioner, because the order of registration was number the subject-matter of appeal before the appellate authority

anchor.surface_text: For example in Amritlal Bhogilal Cos. 1 case it was observed by this Court that the order of regis- tration made by the Income-tax Officer did number merge in the appellate order of the Appellate Commissioner, because the order of registration was number the subject-matter of appeal before the appellate authority. It should be numbericed that the order of assessment made by the Income-Tax Officer in that case was a companyposite order viz., an, order granting registration of the firm and making an assessment on the basis of the registration.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay v. Amritlal Bhogilal & Co.
precedents.cited_proposition: No merger if specific order not subject-matter of appeal
precedents.cited_holding: order of registration did number merge because not subject-matter of appeal; High Court view overruled

precedents.citation: The State of Uttar Pradesh v. Mohammed Nooh 2

anchor.surface_text: Similarly, in The State of Uttar Pradesh v. Mohammed Nooh 2 , it was held by this Court that the principle of merger cannot apply in the case of an order of dismissal of a public servant which was made by the departmental Tribunal on the 20th April, 1948 and against which the appeal was dismissed by the Appellate Authority on the 7th May, 1949, and the revisional application was rejected on the 22nd April, 1950.

precedents.case_name: State of Uttar Pradesh v. Mohammed Nooh
precedents.cited_proposition: Principle of merger does not apply where appeal and revision did not cover the specific order
precedents.cited_holding: principle of merger cannot apply to order of dismissal where appeal dismissed and revisional application rejected

In the circumstances of the present case, it cannot be said that there was a merger of the order of assessment made by the Deputy Commercial Tax Officer dated the 28th November, 1952 with the order of the Deputy Commissioner of Commercial Taxes dated the 21st August, 1954 because the question of exemption on the value of yarn purchased from outside the State of Madras was not the subject-matter of revision before the Deputy Commissioner of Commercial Taxes.
For these reasons, we hold that the judgment of the High Court is right and this appeal must be dismissed with companyts.

But the doctrine of merger is not a doctrine of rigid and universal application and it cannot be said that wherever there are two orders, one by the inferior Tribunal and the other by a superior Tribunal, passed in an appeal on revision, there is a fusion or merger of two orders irrespective of the subject-matter of the appellate or revisional order and the scope of the appeal or revision contemplated by the particular statute.
For these reasons, we hold that the judgment of the High Court is right and this appeal must be dismissed with companyts.
